member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase
member.summary:
Represents the common implementation of the protocol independent definition of any kind of data that can be parsed or generated.
This is the base class of all parsing/generating classes in the phasor protocols library; it is the root of the parsing/generating class hierarchy.
member.remarks: This base class represents data images for parsing or generation in terms of a header, body and footer (see for details).

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase.State
member.summary: Gets or sets the parsing state for this object.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase.Attributes
member.summary: Gets a of string based property names and values for this object.
member.remarks: The attributes dictionary is relevant to all channel properties. This dictionary will only be instantiated with a call to the Attributes property which will begin the enumeration of relevant system properties. This is typically used for display purposes. For example, this information is displayed in a tree view on the the PMU Connection Tester to display attributes of data elements that may be protocol specific.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.ChannelBase.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets a user definable reference to an object associated with this object.

member.summary: Gets the binary image of the object.
member.remarks: This property is not typically overridden since it is the combination of the header, body and footer images.

member.summary: Gets the binary header image of the object.
member.remarks: This property is typically overridden by a specific protocol implementation.

member.summary: Gets the binary body image of the object.
member.remarks: This property is typically overridden by a specific protocol implementation.

member.remarks: This property is typically overridden by a specific protocol implementation.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.ChannelFrameBase`1
member.summary: Represents the protocol independent common implementation of any frame of data that can be sent or received.

remarks.para: This phasor protocol implementation defines a "frame" as a collection of cells (logical units of data). For example, a could be defined as a PMU within a frame of data, a (derived from ), that contains multiple PMU's coming from a PDC.
This class implements the interface so it can be cooperatively integrated into measurement concentration. For more information see the class.

member.param: The reference to the collection of cells for this .

member.summary: Gets or sets the data source identifier for this .

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.ChannelFrameBase`1.AllowQueuedPublication
member.summary: Gets flag that determines if frame image can be queued for publication or should be processed immediately.
member.remarks: Some frames, e.g., a configuration or key frame, may be critical to processing of other frames. In this case, these types of frames should be published immediately so that subsequent frame parsing can have access to needed critical information. All other frames are assumed to be queued by default.

member.remarks: The value of this property represents the number of 100-nanosecond intervals that have elapsed since 12:00:00 midnight, January 1, 0001.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags
member.summary: Protocol independent common status flags enumeration.

remarks.para: These flags are expected to exist in the high-word of a double-word flag set such that original word flags remain in-tact in low-word of double-word flag set.

Note that value being stored in a historian using a 32-bit single precision floating number value will only have castable conversion accuracy back to an unsigned 32-bit integer up to the 24th bit, so any bits used beyond Bit23 will be lossy.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataDiscarded
member.summary: Data was discarded from real-time stream due to late arrival (0 when not discarded, 1 when discarded).

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataIsValid
member.summary: Data is valid (0 when device data is valid, 1 when invalid or device is in test mode).

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.SynchronizationIsValid
member.summary: Synchronization is valid (0 when in device is in sync, 1 when it is not).

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DataSortingType
member.summary: Data sorting type, 0 by timestamp, 1 by arrival.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.DeviceError
member.summary: Device error (including configuration error), 0 when no error.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.ReservedFlags
member.summary: Reserved bits for future common flags, presently set to 0.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.CommonStatusFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.FNET.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.FrameParserBase`1
member.summary: Represents a frame parser that defines the basic functionality for a protocol to parse a binary data stream and return the parsed data via events.
member.remarks:
Frame parsers are implemented as a write-only streams so that data can come from any source.
See for more detail. Note that using the multi-source frame image parser base allows buffers to come in from different channels and still be parsed correctly.
member.typeparam: Frame type identifier used to distinguish frames.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.FrameParserBase`1.RedundantFramesPerPacket
member.summary: Gets the number of redundant frames in each packet.

remarks.para: This value is used when calculating statistics. It is assumed that for each frame that is received, that frame will be included in the next n packets, where n is the number of redundant frames per packet.
This base class returns 0, as most protocols do not support redundant frames.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IChannelParsingState
member.summary:
Represents a protocol independent interface representation of the parsing state used by any kind of data.
This is the base interface implemented by all parsing state classes in the phasor protocols library; it is the root of the parsing state interface hierarchy.
member.remarks: Data parsing is very format specific, classes implementing this interface create a common form for parsing state information particular to a data type.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser
member.summary: Protocol independent frame parser.
member.remarks: This class takes all protocol frame parsing implementations and reduces them to a single simple-to-use class exposing all data through abstract interfaces (e.g., IConfigurationFrame, IDataFrame, etc.) - this way new protocol implementations can be added without adversely affecting consuming code. Additionally, this class implements a variety of transport options (e.g., TCP, UDP, Serial, etc.) and hides the complexities of this connectivity and internally pushes all data received from the selected transport protocol to the selected phasor parsing protocol.

member.name: E:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.SharedTcpServerReference.ReceiveClientData
member.summary: Occurs when unprocessed data has been received from a client.

remarks.para: This event can be used to receive a notification that client data has arrived. The method can then be used to copy data to an existing buffer. In many cases it will be optimal to use an existing buffer instead of subscribing to the event, however, the data that is available after calling the method will be the original unprocessed data received by the client, i.e., not optionally decrypted or decompressed data.

is the ID of the client from which data is received.
is the number of bytes received in the buffer from the client.

member.summary: Occurs when data received from a client has been processed and is ready for consumption.
member.remarks:
is the ID of the client from which data is received.
is a new buffer containing post-processed data received from the client starting at index zero.
is the number of post-processed bytes received in the buffer from the client.

member.summary: Gets or sets flag to automatically send the ConfigFrame2 and EnableRealTimeData command frames used to start a typical data parsing sequence.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.SkipDisableRealTimeData

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.UseHighResolutionInputTimer
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if a high-resolution precision timer should be used for file based input.
member.remarks:
Useful when input frames need be accurately time-aligned to the local clock to better simulate an input device and calculate downstream latencies.
This is only applicable when connection is made to a file for replay purposes.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.DefinedFrameRate
member.summary: Gets or sets desired frame rate to use for maintaining captured frame replay timing.
member.remarks: This is only applicable when connection is made to a file for replay purposes.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.ReplayStartTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the replay start time to use for file based input. File read will begin when encountered frame timestamps are greater than or equal to specified .
member.remarks: This is only applicable when connection is made to a file for replay purposes.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.ReplayStopTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the replay stop time to use for file based input. File read will end when encountered frame timestamps are greater than or equal to specified .
member.remarks: This is only applicable when connection is made to a file for replay purposes.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.InjectSimulatedTimestamp
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating whether or not to inject local system time into parsed data frames.
member.remarks: When connection is made to a file for replay purposes or consumer doesn't trust remote clock source, this flag can be set to true replace all frame timestamps with a UTC timestamp derived from the local system clock.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.AutoRepeatCapturedPlayback
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag that determines if a file used for replaying data should be restarted at the beginning once it has been completed.
member.remarks: This is only applicable when connection is made to a file for replay purposes.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.ConfigurationFrame
member.summary: Gets or sets current used for parsing 's encountered in the data stream from a device.
member.remarks: If a has been parsed, this will return a reference to the parsed frame. Consumer can manually assign a to start parsing data if one has not been encountered in the stream.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.CheckSumValidationFrameTypes
member.summary: Gets or sets flags that determine if check-sums for specified frames should be validated.
member.remarks: It is expected that this will normally be set to .

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.TrustHeaderLength
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that determines if header lengths should be trusted over parsed byte count.
member.remarks: It is expected that this will normally be left as true.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.RedundantFramesPerPacket
member.summary: Gets the number of redundant frames in each packet.
member.remarks: This value is used when calculating statistics. It is assumed that for each frame that is received, that frame will be included in the next n packets, where n is the number of redundant frames per packet.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.MultiProtocolFrameParser.IsIEEEProtocol
member.summary: Gets a flag that determines if the currently selected is an IEEE standard protocol.

member.summary: Gets a flag that determines if the currently selected is connected.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.PhasorValueBase.CalculatePower(GSF.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue,GSF.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue)
member.summary: Calculates watts from imaginary and real components of a voltage and current phasor.
member.exception: and must not be null.
member.returns: Calculated watts from imaginary and real components of specified and phasors.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.PhasorValueBase.CalculateVars(GSF.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue,GSF.PhasorProtocols.IPhasorValue)
member.summary: Calculates vars (total volt-amperes of reactive power) from imaginary and real components of a voltage and current phasor.
member.exception: and must not be null.
member.remarks: Although the units class technically represents watts (i.e., real power) and vars (i.e., imaginary power) are properly expressed in volt-amperes reactive (VAr), the calculated result is still a representation of power and therefore the units class is used to express the return value leaving the consumer to properly apply the needed engineering units for display purposes.
member.returns: Calculated vars (total volt-amperes of reactive power) from imaginary and real components of specified and phasors.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.CommandFrame
member.summary: Represents the IEC 61850-90-5 implementation of a that can be sent or received.
member.remarks: IEC 61850-90-5 command frames are designed only to be sent to a device, not received from a device. As a result this frame does not implement for automated frame parsing. This class exposes a constructor that accepts a binary image in order to manually parse a command frame.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.CommandFrame.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new from the given .
member.param: Start index into to begin parsing.
member.remarks: This constructor is used by a consumer to parse a received IEC 61850-90-5 command frame. Typically command frames are sent to a device. This constructor would used if this code was being used inside of a phasor measurement device.
member.exception: is not large enough to parse frame.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.DigitalDefinition.GetLabel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the individual labels for specified bit in this .
member.param: Index of desired bit label to access.

remarks.para: In the final version of the protocol each digital bit can be labeled, but we read them out as one big string in the "Label" property so this property allows individual access to each label.
Note that the draft 6 implementation of the protocol supports one label for all 16-bits, however draft 7 (i.e., version 1) supports a label for each of the 16 bits.

member.returns: A value of the label corresponding to the parameter.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.DigitalDefinition.SetLabel(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the individual labels for specified bit in this .
member.param: Index of desired bit label to access.
Value of the bit label to assign.

remarks.para: In the final version of the protocol each digital bit can be labeled, but we read them out as one big string in the "Label" property so this property allows individual access to each label.
Note that the draft 6 implementation of the protocol supports one label for all 16-bits, however draft 7 (i.e., version 1) supports a label for each of the 16 bits.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEC61850_90_5.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.BPAPDCstream.FrameParser.ParseWordCountFromByte
member.summary: Gets or sets flag that interprets word count in packet header from a byte instead of a word.
member.remarks: Set to true to interpret word count in packet header from a byte instead of a word - if the sync byte (0xAA) is at position one, then the word count would be interpreted from byte four. Some older BPA PDC stream implementations have a 0x01 in byte three where there should be a 0x00 and this throws off the frame length, setting this property to true will correctly interpret the word count.

member.name: P:GSF.PhasorProtocols.BPAPDCstream.FrameParser.UsePhasorDataFileFormat

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.BPAPDCstream.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.summary: Raises the event.

member.param: that was parsed by that implements protocol specific common frame header interface.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEEE1344.CommandFrame
member.summary: Represents the IEEE 1344 implementation of a that can be sent or received.
member.remarks: IEEE 1344 command frames are designed only to be sent to a device, not received from a device. As a result this frame does not implement for automated frame parsing. This class exposes a constructor that accepts a binary image in order to manually parse a command frame.

member.param: Start index into to begin parsing.
member.remarks: This constructor is used by a consumer to parse a received IEEE 1344 command frame. Typically command frames are sent to a device. This constructor would used if this code was being used inside of a phasor measurement device.
member.exception: must be at least 16.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEEE1344.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEEEC37_118.CommandFrame
member.summary: Represents the IEEE C37.118 implementation of a that can be sent or received.
member.remarks: IEEE C37.118 command frames are designed only to be sent to a device, not received from a device. As a result this frame does not implement for automated frame parsing. This class exposes a constructor that accepts a binary image in order to manually parse a command frame.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEEEC37_118.CommandFrame.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new from the given .
member.param: Start index into to begin parsing.
member.remarks: This constructor is used by a consumer to parse a received IEEE C37.118 command frame. Typically command frames are sent to a device. This constructor would used if this code was being used inside of a phasor measurement device.
member.exception: is not large enough to parse frame.

member.summary: Creates a new from specified parameters.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEEEC37_118.DigitalDefinition.GetLabel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the individual labels for specified bit in this .
member.param: Index of desired bit label to access.

remarks.para: In the final version of the protocol each digital bit can be labeled, but we read them out as one big string in the "Label" property so this property allows individual access to each label.
Note that the draft 6 implementation of the protocol supports one label for all 16-bits, however draft 7 (i.e., version 1) supports a label for each of the 16 bits.

member.returns: A value of the label corresponding to the parameter.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEEEC37_118.DigitalDefinition.SetLabel(System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the individual labels for specified bit in this .
member.param: Index of desired bit label to access.
Value of the bit label to assign.

remarks.para: In the final version of the protocol each digital bit can be labeled, but we read them out as one big string in the "Label" property so this property allows individual access to each label.
Note that the draft 6 implementation of the protocol supports one label for all 16-bits, however draft 7 (i.e., version 1) supports a label for each of the 16 bits.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.IEEEC37_118.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.HeaderFrame.ChecksumIsValid(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Determines if checksum in the is valid.
member.param: Start index into to perform checksum.
member.returns: Flag that determines if checksum over is valid.
member.remarks: Default implementation expects 2-byte big-endian ordered checksum. So we override method since checksum in Macrodyne is a single byte.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.HeaderFrame.AppendChecksum(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Appends checksum onto starting at .
member.param: Buffer image on which to append checksum.
Index into where checksum should be appended.
member.remarks: Default implementation encodes checksum in big-endian order and expects buffer size large enough to accomodate 2-byte checksum representation. We override this method since checksum in Macrodyne is a single byte.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags
member.summary: Macrodyne clock status flags enumeration (from byte 1 in time string).

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.DacBeyondLimits
member.summary: Set when DAC811 adjustment on the GPS board is beyond limits.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.GpsComIssue
member.summary: Set when the time output is that from the internal buffer (in GPS board processor) incremented by one second.
member.remarks: This implies a problem in communication between the GPS receiver and GPS board.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.GpsUnlocked
member.summary: Set when the internal oscillator is not disciplined (the GPS clock is not locked).

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.GpsTimeInvalid
member.summary: Set when the last GPS receiver time tag was invalid.
member.remarks: The data was received, but flagged as invalid. This may be caused by a loss of satellite visibility.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.ResynchronizationPending
member.summary: Set when the system is about to be resynchronized to the GPS receiver.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.ErrorCondition
member.summary: Set when an error condition exists.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.UsingLocalTime
member.summary: Set for local time mode, cleared for UTC mode.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.ClockAndReceiverOutOfSync
member.summary: Set when the GPS clock 1 PPS and the GPS receiver 1 PPS differ by more than 5 microseconds.

member.name: F:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.ClockStatusFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.Macrodyne.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.summary: Writes a sequence of bytes onto the stream for parsing.
member.param: Defines the source channel for the data.
An array of bytes. This method copies count bytes from buffer to the current stream.
The zero-based byte offset in buffer at which to begin copying bytes to the current stream.
The number of bytes to be written to the current stream.

member.name: T:GSF.PhasorProtocols.SelFastMessage.CommandFrame
member.summary: Represents the SEL Fast Message implementation of a that can be sent or received.
member.remarks: SEL Fast Message command frames are designed only to be sent to a device, not received from a device. As a result this frame does not implement for automated frame parsing. This class exposes a constructor that accepts a binary image in order to manually parse a command frame.

member.name: M:GSF.PhasorProtocols.SelFastMessage.FrameParser.ParseCommonHeader(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Parses a common header instance that implements for the output type represented in the binary image.
member.param: Offset index into buffer that represents where to start parsing.
Maximum length of valid data from offset.
member.returns: The which includes a type ID for the to be parsed.

remarks.para: Derived classes need to provide a common header instance (i.e., class that implements ) for the output types; this will primarily include an ID of the that the data image represents. This parsing is only for common header information, actual parsing will be handled by output type via its method. This header image should also be used to add needed complex state information about the output type being parsed if needed.

If there is not enough buffer available to parse common header (as determined by ), return null. Also, if the protocol allows frame length to be determined at the time common header is being parsed and there is not enough buffer to parse the entire frame, it will be optimal to prevent further parsing by returning null.

member.summary: Queues a sequence of bytes, from the specified data source, onto the stream for parsing.
member.param: An array of bytes. This method copies count bytes from buffer to the queue.
The zero-based byte offset in buffer at which to begin copying bytes to the current stream.
The number of bytes to be written to the current stream.
